>>27992706
Whereabouts do you live?
I am not qualified to give medical advice so don't want to recommend anything that may make it worse. Though it does sound like you may have a significant wax build-up in your ears and the infection may have returned. Do you use any foreign objects to clean your ears btw, what are you using to scrape out the gunk? I know the classic trick of putting like 2-3 drops of medical grade olive/almond oil in your ears 3 to 4 times a day for a few days, though if your hearing is impacted I'd be careful. I agree with the other anon, if it's an ongoing issue ideally you want another proper consultation to assess your options.
Anyway yeah, I don't know what the medical system is like where you live but but (at least once things re-open - here it's the 28th) try ringing up GP surgeries; you may be able to register as a temporary patient and see somebody before you travel (had to do this for a few people last week as a clinic receptionist). Don't be afraid to call back to chase things up or see if a sooner appointment has freed up. Else try walk-in centers and clinics (just appreciate wait times around Xmas...); I don't know if you can afford to see a specialist privately. Receiving consistent medical care with continuity is difficult if you keep travelling so... yeah, try to do that less next month lol. Hope your ear feels better soon.

I hid in the secret tunnels and compartments in the mansion while trying to convince them that no one lived in these rich, ivory halls, totally lit with electricity, going as far as leaving a body from the crypts in the study, like "oh, THIS is the old owner."
As soon as I came out of the tunnels, though, I found out that more of them had arrived, and they were all comparing notes in the rear garden. One of them looked up and spotted me, and I leapt through the bay window. All I knew was that they couldn't know about me, they couldn't be allowed to threaten my cozy isolation in the woods. I think I get what she meant when she said I wasn't "excited about life." I have no long term or short term goals for myself, only vague dreams of becoming a famous writer and starting a family. I would've been comfortable spending the rest of my life curled into a ball on that couch, lying next to her like a cat, and she probably knew that and knew it wasn't good.
I'm "going places" right now, 3/4 way through a degree that'll put me in a good spot in life and give me the opportunity to move away and build my future, but it doesn't actually mean anything to me. I have as much emotional attachment to this path in life as I would had I spent the past four years digging a hole. At the same time it's the only sense of direction I have. Without it I know I'd just rot in my room until the weight of my parents' disappointment led me to an hero.
One of my friends in high school shot himself. In front of his dad, too, with his gun. We sat next to eachother in programming class one year, and though I didn't think much of our talks it's possible that I was one of his only friends. He was always smiling, odd and dim but never depressed. But he didn't last more than a month after graduation. What led him to give up? What inner turmoil must he have had for him to look his pleading father in the eye and choose death instead?

He was 18 then. I'm 22 now, about to turn 23. I have a good home situation, the resources and means to finish my degree, some online friends that I've known for years, and I'm generally happy, but I lack the will to live. How long can I go on without it?

>>27991218
I think we are doing what we're doing because we think that there's a small chance that by letting our person really have it that they will then understand us. We're still chasing that understanding no matter how slight that chance is. We're chasing that missed connection we wanted. We're looking to fill that traumatically formed void which has been left occupying some space within us where we want "their" love to be--and it's just not there. It goes unfulfilled and that's why we rage against the night. Ours is irrational behavior, because the person who we wish understood us is never going to understand. They're never going to come around. Things are never going to change. They're never going to care about us. And we have to accept that. Otherwise it's just going to keep eating at us the way it's doing now. Our fighting against it does nothing productive and only pushes them further--the functional opposite of what we want. It's just self-harm, and other-harm. And we'll continue lashing and resenting and being volatile until we finally say to ourselves, "that's how I was before; but I don't have to be that way anymore."

But we have to mean it. We have to want THAT change more than we want the thing we wanted so much before. And if our traumas are a comorbidity with our learned and ingrained method of self-expression (maladaptive expression), then changing the one must, by necessity, include a changing of the other. We must change the way we act and react. Our behavior there fuels the fires of our trauma, so to speak. Except instead of staying warm we just end up immolating ourselves and it's most certainly not a blaze of glory. It's just foolishness. We need to extinguish, not feed. Feeding feels cathartic, but we must understand that it's a fleeting catharsis. It's healing is only momentarily so. For something lasting we need the kind of change that lasts. And it's not *this*

/blog

You most likely come across like an idiot or an asshole when you argue.

People impulsively do not want to listen to good sense. If the person speaking is being rude or nasty to us, we don't wanna hear what they have to say. It's stupid, but we all do this shit. You see it all the time on /adv/. OP asks for advice. Anon gives good advice, but is kind of a dick about it. OP ignores the good advice, and chooses to have a cry because anon was mean. The good advice goes unheeded.

Unfortunately, the content of your arguments means sweet fuck all if you cannot express them in a way that is palatable to your audience.
'Palatable' is different from person to person, but some good general pointers for better arguing include:

>Not insulting the opinions or the intelligence of your audience. Don't call them retarded for having a POV you disagree with (even if you're right).
>Taking the time to hear their point of view, acknowledge their good points, and politely criticise the flaws in their argument
>If you're about to say something conspiracy-theory-ish or very un-PC, try to acknowledge the instinctive misgivings of your audience.
"Hey, I know this is gonna sound schizo af and you're gonna laugh at me, but I really think 9-11 was an inside job."
>Acknowledging the flaws in your own argument and any good opposing points, and being good at adjusting your stance accordingly.
>Allow your opposition a little 'win' early on by empathising with their pov. It makes them more susceptible to acknowledging the sense in your bigger arguments. Everyone wants to think of themselves as logical. It's a fucking lie we tell ourselves to feel smart and stoic. Appeal to emotion to calm your opponent, THEN hit them with the logic.
>No swearing or raising your voice. Remain chill and amiable.
>If you slip and insult them, soften it immediately lol.

It seems like you have a charisma issue more than anything else. Develop those people skills and you'll be golden, mate.

What kind of girls are you hitting up? You have to remember that girls mainly want one thing from relationships: containment. They want a guy who is going to make them feel safe, secure, and comfortable in their own skin. So ideally you should only be hitting up girls who are:

>shorter than you by 2+ inches
>younger than you by 2+ years
>clearly more feminine than you
>less ambitious than you
>not much wealthier than you
>not much wiser than you

If you're using dating apps you can figure most of this stuff out by their profiles and photos. Of course, you still have to take chances. But focusing on this stuff should ideally help you get rejected less because you'll stop reaching out to girls that you know are "high risk" for you.

Less than 1% is very, very incorrect.
The actual rate of infection is somewhere between 3% and 10%, depending on the study.

Most people are carriers of the disease. Many people are immune. But in some cases, it can cause serious complications and fuck people up for life.
If a pregnant woman gives birth while having symptoms, her baby can get infected and can potentially go blind or die as a result of contact with the virus.
It can occur around the mouth (genital and oral herpes don't just occur in the obvious places), which is embarrassing.
It's painful af when you have sores.

Legally, you might not be required to disclose this information, but you a cunt of the highest magnitude if you do not disclose it.
You deserve to be alone forever if you don't share this information. Because it's a health issue, you aren't being honest, and because you're probably be pretty fucking pissed that someone did it to you, too, huh?

Source: I have herpes. I'm not a whore. I'm not a loser. So when I have sex, I let the other person know in advance.

posts.com:
Honestly, just tell her outright that you find conversation really dry and painful via text. Ask her if she feels the same way.
Try to work on ways to keep the conversation going smoothly, and practice saying outright "I've run out of things to say, and you seem done too. Talk later. Love you. Bye."

Sometimes just rambling without really thinking about what's coming out of your mouth is really helpful. One of my favourite conversationalists has ADHD so she just blurts out random shit without thinking. It's great for me, because I'm so reserved and quiet that I don't have to work much on the conversation. Try to encourage her to do the same thing. Act really enthusiastic to make her want to talk more.

It might be good to ask her outright "hey, can you carry these conversations a little more? I'm losing my fucking mind here."

You've been together for 6 years. I'm sure you can afford to be honest with her lol.

My sister and her partner have been together for almost 20 years. They're great together and can play/joke/talk easy, but sometimes even they have boring phone calls. It used to be really bad when her partner did a lot of travelling for work, because he'd call multiple times a day because he was lonely and missed her. But then they'd have nothing to talk about, so she'd get kind of bored and annoyed. She empathised and felt terrible about it, but it was too much. Eventually she set a rule that he's only allowed to call once per day lol. The relationship never suffered for it. It actually seemed to improve.

Having interesting lives also helps. Go out and do new things/try new foods/visit new places/hang out with people and have interesting conversations and make funny moments. Encourage your girl to do the same. Then talk about it together. It's hard to have a fun conversation when you've sat on your ass playing videogames all day.

Idk, honesty seems like the best approach here.

Cut off any coomerb8. Stop visiting all red boards, maybe even all of 4chan because faggots post shit even on blue boards, unfollow all the insta thots, stop watching amouranth or whatever degen shit you do. Make a new yt acc if your recommendations are filled with coomerb8.

WAGMI. Stay strong

I had had problems beforehand, about a year leading up to it I would randomly get pressure in my ears I could never pop depending on how hot I was. Since getting the water in my ears - which I felt going further in before soaking away - I have had much pain daily that has lessened over the years but still is present. It tends to run from deep in the ears to the front of the forehead. About 9 months after the water went in the daily extreme pain subsided and was replaced by me needing to crack my jaw joints multiple times a day.

I have been to the doctor multiple times and spent a lot of money on prescriptions. First one gave me a round of antibiotics. Three further visits all prescribed me ear drops (don’t remember the chemical, one of them was something ending in Otic). posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: What are the most effective methods for overcoming porn and masturbation addiction?
posts.com: Title^. What has worked for you anons? Any good sources, books, articles, videos, etc. that helped you or look promising?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
AVRT is the only thing that ever helped me, see https://youtu.be/S53OjsF3z-w. For years I felt totally helpless. I tried nofap and easypeasy but couldnt make it work at all. AVRT however, hits different.

With AVRT you learn that your midbrain has associated your addiction with survival and that it will compel you (your neocortex, your rational thinking self) to use even if it means your own destruction.

Step one in AVRT is to make the "I/IT" distinction. You learn to separate what YOU want from what the primitive (beast) midbrain wants. It will become obvious to you that this is what is really happening in your brain.

Addiction is ambivalence and quitting addiction is putting and end to that ambivalence. Ambivalence means you are of two choices: You really want to keep using porn but at the same time want to quit. You cant reconcile these two extremes and likely do not understand it yet, but its simple. Its I vs IT. The you that matters vs the primitive midbrain beast.

Step two is learning to recognize the addictive voice. Once recognized your thoughts untangle themselves. You decide to stick with your choice instead of what this midbrain compels you to do.

Step three is strengthening your grip over the addictive voice. You mainly do it through the technique of shifting. It means letting the beast out and then reining it in over and over again. You can see it in action in the second part of the video series and its very powerful. It put a tear in my eye because again I realized that for most of my life I have been ruled over by my midbrain.

I cant keep on explaining. Please watch the videos, read the book later. I am very curious what any objection might be to AVRT because from what I can tell its just perfect.

Keep at it. Try to see if you RR can help you with the AV. But read carefully because it takes a certain approach to beat it completely. >>27990827
Alcohol is a pointless, fruitless endeavor. Ever since I invented a workaround for it, I've had literally no reason to drink besides taste tests and parties.

The key to my workaround is to understand on fundamental level what alcohol does to you mentally. Why are you drinking it? To numb the pain? To forget about life? These are bad and you shouldn't be after this. Face your issues and stop getting addicted to shit that keeps you from facing your issues. Good example >>27990831

For me, I realized that I was drinking because it made me more social. I was loosened up. My anxieties, fears, etc went away. So, I just found that groove of getting loose and having a good time/letting shit go, and after some practice I realized I can let shit go and have fun without the need for alcohol. I can have the same fun, exhilarating experience that alcohol promises, minus the alcohol. All because I knew what it does to me mentally.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27992673
Dreams are your brain flushing out the excess emotions of the day, for much the same reason you flush a toilet. To do it, your brain dresses up the emotions in specific plot or situations drawn from your memory and imagination banks.

The factual details of your dreams are not significant - they're just what the brain picked at random. It's the emotional content - in your case the feelings of being trapped and endangered - that are the key. SOMETHING in your real ife is overloading you with those emotions, and the dreams are getting rid of them as much as possible.

Figure out what makes you feel dread in real life, and either change it or find ways to cope with it, and the nightmares will go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27990334
Pretty privilege exists, but confidence and not being an idiot socially are what you're missing if you don't have friends or relationships.

Genuinely be interested in what people have to say, get good at small talk, and do your best to be comfortable in your own skin. People love to talk about themselves and the things they're interested in, so get them to explain things to you with thoughtful questions and add your own contributions. Similarly, find a hobby that people can associate with you and can ask you about - golf, running, local sports leagues, cooking, etc. Be upbeat, positive, and energetic so they want to talk to you.

Also be reasonably fit. Ugly athletic people are more attractive than ugly fat or skinny people. Don't be a gym bro though, just active and able to do 50 push ups.

Lastly, all this sort of snowballs. People like people that other people like. Get some people to like you, hang out with them around people who don't know you, and get more people to like you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dreams are just short term memory from the day being overlaid onto long term memory through the visual cortex.

There is no more meaning to this than you had a passing lustful thought about her in the day. It's irrelevant, stop giving dreams more meaning than they actually have.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27992168
Developing a crush isn't a crime. It happens - even to married men and women. You are committing no crime, and have no intentions of betraying your wife. And it seems that this girl is not interested in doing anything with you, either.
Don't stress, man. You're all good.

This is gonna sound terrible and counterintuitive, but have you tried leaning into the thoughts and forcing yourself to think about those dreams and imagine the scenario on purpose? Sometimes compulsive thoughts and dreams like this than affect you extra-strongly purely because you're trying so hard to ignore them, because they bring you shame or make you uncomfortable.
Sometimes looking those thoughts/fantasies in the eye and aggressively tearing them apart while analysing your own feelings about the whole thing can make them lose their power over you, and you feel much better afterwards.

I know, because I've had similarly inappropriate dreams and compulsive thoughts during the day that left me feeling sick and uncomfortable. I overcame them by forcing myself to pick the dreams apart and forcing myself to imagine them in detail, and analysing my feelings towards them as I did so. I never had those dreams again, and the compulsive thoughts went away.
I've done the same thing with other compulsive thoughts and obsessions.

Apparently this is a really good tactic for OCD sufferers. If it works for them, and it's worked for me, it'll hopefully work for you, too.

And hey, remember: there's nothing wrong with liking the IDEA of what your dreams are portraying. Dreams are only dreams. Thoughts are only thoughts. It's your actions that make the man.

I hadn't thought about clowns or seen clown pictures or anything like that AT ALL aside from that one brief millisecond of thought about clowns.

Dreams almost always cover something that you've thought about during the day. Sleep is when your body sorts your memories and learning from the day into the correct filing system.
So of course your dreams will sometimes have meaning. They often feature things that are bothering you. If you've thought about something stressful all day, you'll likely dream about it, too. But not always. Sometimes your dreams will be about clowns.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27991983
When you can’t even make a few days, it’s because you don’t really want to. If this means something to you, then get serious about it. There’s a mental state where you will succeed at quitting, but you have to care enough to stay conscious and keep yourself in this state. You’re letting yourself drift into not caring about it. And just to let you know, even after I discovered that fact for myself, I still wasted another full year getting serious.

Don’t hide from anything you feel. Learn to relax with it, and to maintain your true will. And understand that you need to be 100 times more serious about it. You can FEEL when things start to slide, but I guarantee you just put on a video game or youtube video and pretend you’ve got this. These emotions are going to entice you to do it, and you have to learn to get yourself away from that. You’re never going to learn, unless you take each attempt as seriously as if it’s your only attempt.

For example… Let’s say you’re feeling the urge. What does it feel like to decide that you’re not going to? It’ll feel heavy, annoying, tense. You’re probably going to get pissy about it. I’ll leave you with one secret. That feeling is good. When you can stop trying to make life not feel that way, stop using it as a reason to make excuses for yourself and letting yourself off the hook in a million ways, and instead learn to use that feeling constructively, then life will change for you…

posts.name: Anonymous

Addiction in any sense, anon, is a result of a choice.
>Take the rational choice, study in school, get a good job/find a fulfilling career, spend time with those company you enjoy, etc
>Maximize temporary pleasure and ignore the future
If you are choosing the second, consistently, then it is because your first choice is not good enough. If you do not derive pleasure in your day-to-day life, figure out what it is that irks you. Do you have psychological issues? Self-esteem problems? Lack of support? Fix all of these, and dropping the addiction, at least for less addictive substances like pornography, becomes so increadibly easy that it is natural.

posts.com:
something I've noticed after being sheltered all my life, and finally beginning to learn social skills is that while a lot of people like to talk, no one wants to listen.

what are some good tips beyond the general advice given on websites about being a better listener?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27991009

Listening is one of the best skills.

When you listen, don't say anything until they're done talking. You can ask short questions in between sentences though, to better grasp what they're talking about.

Don't pay attention to things around you when you're listening. You get what they're saying better when you're giving all your attention.

Imagine yourself in the shoes of the person you're listening to. See what they see, hear what they hear, try to get where they're coming from, feel what they're feeling as they talk.

Have a neutral but attentive face. People will say crazy shit, the more poker face you have to things, the more they feel they can honestly say to you without you giving an unwanted reaction, even via facial expression.

Learn from everything you hear. Be careful with what you believe, but there is absolutely something to be learned from every sentence you hear. The more you listen and think, the more you will be able to analyze new people. You'll pick up on different details of the same story from different people, you'll start to kind of be able to predict people from their early mannerisms, vibes, tone of voice, word choice, body movements, etc.

When you're listening, you're just trying to 'get' something. You don't need to form an actual opinion, or respond in a certain way.

As you said, a lot of people want to talk. Listeners are powerful, there's not a lot of them, but they compliment talkers so well

If they haven't answered what they were last talking about, try following up with things like, "well how'd that end up" or of that nature. Of course the context will dictate your responses or questions to the conversation.

Sometimes if you've lost your train of thought you can be like, repeat that or go back to something earlier from the convo & build on that, although that is usually a sign of being in an awkward convo.

Best way to remember tho is reacting to something every so often, experiences are what you'll remember & it'll be easier to react to something at times than to think of what to say.

What works for me is for every person I meet and I know I might run into them again, I try to associate them with one thing they have mentioned which is key to them. An example, their kids or their commute or their vacation. Next time you see them you can simply be like "how are the kids?" Or "how was your commute today?". They will keep talking and talking and you can take a moment to relax and learn one mode thing. It's ok if you don't get that one thing all the time. But little by little. Like you said, no one likes to listen, but they all love to talk about themselves and you come through as caring by asking them about something key to them

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27992625
Unironically, this.

>>27992486
Instead of giving yourself a set amount of time for breaks each day, instead give yourself a set amount of hours to spend on the project. Think of them as your 'work hours'.
Outside of work, you DO NOT FUCKING THINK ABOUT WORK.

This weekend, set a limit of 5 hours to work on your project. Give yourself a half-hour break in the middle.
At the end of those 5 hours, fuck off and do something else. Lock the door to the room where your project is waiting. Leave the house. Take a nap. Lay in the bath until the water goes cold. Play videogames. Do whatever you want, but do not even LOOK in the direction of your project.

That's pretty much all you can do, man.

If you're on a deadline, just get that shit done and then learn from the experience. Start finding ways to prevent this from happening again.

Typically, I never ask women out when they're on the job. If that's only time I can see them though, instead of stalking them I just ask them if they want to have a cup of coffee on their break or after work.

They key is to make it soon/immediate so there's no planning, and thus no chance of being able to cancel. Ask her to meet you at a local coffee shop at some time. She knows what you look like, so that's all she needs. Then you can go from there.

Asking for a number is too specific and too forward in a work setting. There's a reason you don't see too many guys asking for their Denny's waitresses phone number out in public. It's because when they're on a job, they're being paid to be nice to you. If you put them on the spot like that, not only do you make their life a lot worse, but you embarrass yourself and everyone else around you. That's why you got to be subtle.

Good luck dude, get that puss bro

>How feasible is it to live in a place like Thailand for around 500 bucks a month or less?
>rent
Go on fazwaz, or dare I say Craigslist, and see what the prices are. The lowest you could conceivably go on rent is like $150 and that's gonna be outside Farang ghettos and in a non-centralized location. It probably doesn't include utilities either
>muh hostel!
You'd be lucky to find $5 dollars a night
>food
A single Thai dish with rice is like $1.5-3 dollars. Anything western is obviously more expensive. So if you wanted to keep your food budget low you'd have to eat Thai food pretty strictly; either from a hole in the wall restaurant or food cart
>misc
So let's say did that. You're left with $170. That's only about 5000 baht. Lowest monthly rate you could get for a motorbike rental is like 3000 baht = $3 dollars a day. Moto taxis are at least a dollar per trip, even on an app like bolt.
You'd also have to factor in the cost of an ED visa (IMO that's the best visa to stay for ~1 year).

So bottom line you could probably survive "comfortably" imo but that's about it. I don't think you'd find it particularly pleasant though. $1000/mo is a lot more ideal.

It sounds like she's either misunderstood the terms of your relationship and believes that you ARE together in some capacity (in which case, she is being a shit partner), or she is trying to keep you emotionally tethered to her, without having to deal with the responsibilities of actually being your GF. Either way, it's an issue. You need to hammer that out with her. Be blunt.

The topic of her weight sounds like an insecurity issue. Clearly you are interested in this girl. She probably doesn't feel like she is good enough for you, because of her appearance. Sadly, that's pretty common. But if she can't shake that feeling, it's gonna permeate into the rest of the relationship. This is a tricky topic to navigate tactfully, but I think it's important to be tactful and supportive, without lying. If she's too fat, tell her. But be supportive and encouraging, and remind her of her attractive qualities, too. If you are worried about her self-esteem, talk to her about it. Try to encourage her to make positive changes in life, but remind her to do it for HER - not YOU.

It's good that you guys still talk about personal stuff and talk frequently. But I want to know - do you guys have fun together? Do you play/joke together, and enjoy one another's company? I ask because it sounds like you guys don't really...enjoy each other? It sounds like you like her, and she just feels like she NEEDS you, you know? Like - for her own self-esteem reasons. She's not treating you with fairly, but seems overly attached. It sounds like you aren't in a happy relationship. You need to feel GOOD when you're together. It's not enough to just feel 'not bad'. The best way to make amends depends on the relationship and on the circumstances. Making direct amends isn't always beneficial. No longer being in contact with a person is one of the times where it might be better for you to make amends symbolically or indirectly. You could pray for forgiveness and a clear conscience, you could write a letter to the person you harmed and never send it, or you could just live out the changes in your mindset and behavior to demonstrate to yourself, the people who still matter in your life, and the new people you meet that you're not the same person as before.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27986111
You need to take this much more seriously. You want to stop. To keep falling in every other day and keep telling yourself you’ll stop is so far below the minimum acceptable level of seriousness. You need to go to a greater depth. With the understanding that as you do so, you also increase the stakes. You risk hurting yourself and collapsing your soul when you try really hard and you still end up betraying yourself. You can beat yourself into the ground, and end up allowing yourself to quit.

On your longeste streak, you had a degree of seriousness about you, that outpaced anything you’ve experienced since. And you failed because you got away from that. To succeed at this, is to understand that you have to not only stay that serious, but become even more serious.

As you do that, you’re going to start to experience a lot of things bubbling to the surface. You’re going to get annoyed, you’ll feel doubt etc, and since you keep failing, I can conclude that you don’t realize that you’ve started to feel these things until it is too late. They are real concerns that you have to look at and grapple with. Ignore them, and they win. Unfortunately none of that feels good, and that means you have to be willing to feel bad sometimes, while you figure these things out. That’s just the rules of the game. And as you face those things, don’t forget that you said you wanted to quit. And you can do it. Be aware that every decision you make, any thought you let yourself think, you’re creating your identity.

Some of the more toxic thoughts you may feel compelled to underways are: I don’t even care anyway. Just once doesn’t hurt. I’m not doing anything good with my time anyway. I’m not gonna get a girlfriend anyway. I don’t even deserve a good life anyway. I’m useless anyway.

If you pay close attention, you will face yourself like that. All your most toxic shit will come up. And you have to ask yourself if that’s who you want to be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Because they are never simple truths. They are little mental programs, little units of thought and emotion that you’ve been trained with (and you helped too), and you’ve taken a certain like to them. When people absolutely destroy themselves, there’s a part of them that likes it, at least in the moment. They don’t like it when they have to pick up the tab. That’s why it’s extremely important to always look at what you’re feeling, and what thoughts you’re having, and ask yourself if those thoughts serve you, if they will lead you where you want to go, and if they are who you want to be.

Lots of people choose from two options: letting yourself get away with absolutely anything and telling yourself it’s only human. This makes them soulless and weak. Or they want to be great, but think they can get there by punishing themselves and being an asshole to themselves. Both of these are too emotional. You have to find out that you are greater than your emotions. And truly loving yourself is the same as no longer being a slave to what feels good. It’s to understand that life is not bad because you feel bad right now. You can feel bad, and still be at peace, because you’re doing what you think is right. That will give you self-respect like nothing else. Can’t be bought or faked.

turn off your shit.

go sit.

posts.sub: How to be a better person
posts.com:
This is going to be a long one, so I’m sorry to everyone who’ll read it and thanks to everyone who’ll give me an advice and a word of wisdom.

To give you some background I was the classic case of a gifted kid underachiever, always praised for how smart I am and what not, even though that I fluked everything, got bad grades and generally developed a really unhealthy lifestyle where I refused to take part in activities that I didn’t care for or didn’t immediately benefit me, which is one of the worst thing that anyone can fall into. I loved watching movies and reading books, finding new interesting music and what not, very much a shut-in, when I was not watching movies or reading, I was pretty much just scrolling 4chan.

So here I am now, at the age of 27, still the same retarded lazy mindset. I dropped out of college couple years back and have been later hired as a videographer and video editor into this small educational company. I’ve been employed there for almost year and a half now, I feel like this is the path that I want to walk career wise. I’ve really grown as an editor and a videographer, going from basically zero experience to a decent level of technical expertise. It’s a chill job, sometimes it’s chill way too much in a way that old bad habits that never really went are more present than ever – postponing really simple tasks that I rather stress about for prolonged period of time rather than resolving them right away, procrastinating most of the days lately and so on. I kinda feel like the job has nothing more to offer me anymore, I feel like I’ve reached the top there and there’s not much else to learn on the current position. I’m the only one in the video department, I’ve selftaught myself everything and I have no one to look up to, which could really benefit me I think.


(1/3)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Thing is the pay is really low I pay the rent and everything else that needs to be payed and that’s it, I’m scraping the barrel for the rest of the month. For the time being in the company I wasn’t able to save up the money for the gear, to start thinking about freelancing – camera, laptop, lenses etc. Even if I had, I’m rather introverted and as I said, the underachievist mindset is still holding me down and I’m not sure I’d be able to sell myself up there on the free market.

So that’s some of the things that are bugging me down, I’m getting to the major ones. Everyday I’m gradually more and more pissed about myself wasting time away, not doing anything when I get back home from work, even though I have a girlfriend I feel like I’m terribly empty, with nothing interesting going on. As mentioned in the beginning, people thought that I was really smart when was younger, I don’t think they’d think it now. I feel like I really gotten myself down with all that procrastinating, most of the time I spend on my phone scrolling facebook, mindlessly sitting on a couch, wasting time away. Sometimes I grab a book, but as I mentioned before, things doesn’t work for me when I have to force myself into them. So I fold it down, and grab the phone again. This is fucking retarded but it’s like a vicious addicting circle that I can’t escape, or I don’t know where to escape to. I really want to be more productive beginning the new year, to be honest I’m lost and as my girlfriend said a couple times, I haven’t matured probably. I really want to turn myself around, for me and for my girlfriend. She’s amazing (we’ve been together for almost four years now), I love her and unfortunately I feel like she’s the type of person that needs to be guided too and I feel like I’ve been dragging her down with my inactivity lately.

>>27987296
First of all: congrats anon, on applying yourself in a new skill and teaching yourself to be proficient at it. I hope this is one of your lifelong passions you can pursue to mastery.

It sounds like your issue is lack of clear, defined direction, and you haven't properly created long-term goals or how to obtain them. You need to get organized. Sometimes your environment can play into this; maybe there's many distractions at home, maybe it's messy, so start there if so. Next, sit down and take time, as much as you need, to consider where you want to be in 1 year, then 5, then 10, and so on. Figure out the ideal future for you at these milestones, whether it's to have a new job with more room to grow in 1 year, or to own your own home in 10, and clearly define where you think you would like to be. Then, take apart these larger goals into all of the small things you need to accomplish to get there, what you need to do to do the things you want to do, then, what you can do today to do those things. Break it all down to the smalles level until you have what is essentially a "chore" list that you perform daily towards your future improvement. If it's weight loss for example, in 1 year you want to lose 50 lbs, weekly you want to lose 1 pound, figure your caloric/nutritional budget daily, then your daily needed deficit to accomplish it, then every day you work on that. In a year's time, maybe you only lose 49 lbs, maybe you lose less, but by the very act of setting out to accomplish something, you're almost guaranteed to be closer to your goal than not. Don't let perfect be the enemy of good. Just keep trying, keep your goals clear and stick to your daily commitment to yourself. This is how all problems are handled, and all large goals are accomplished. Dream of the bigger picture, organize how to get there, and break it down into what you can do every day to move closer to it. If you do this, buddy, you can go anywhere you want in life. Good luck anon.

posts.com:
>>27987910
Discpline is simply a habit. I know "simply" isn't fair to say about what is often very hard to do, but it really is simple despite being hard. All a habit is is time+consistency. The more you do something, the longer you do it, the less active effort or motivation it takes to keep up with it, until it becomes as natural as anything you do every day, and eventually becomes a part of your way of life. It doesn't stay hard. You don't have to worry about perfect. If you start a diet, some days you will cheat, some days you will eat over your limit, no matter what you do occasional failures should be expected, and are not a bad thing. The important thing is to do *something*, anything, if even a small step, and work past the stumbles and setbacks. So long as you are facing forward, it doesn't matter if you're crawling, you will get there eventually. Time will pass regardless, in 5 years 5 years will have passed whether you pass it doing nothing or having accomplished what you set out to, you may as well give it a try, even if you're crawling there. Crawling will lead to walking, and, if you keep going, eventually you'll be marathon-running through your goals. Progress leads to more progress, the snowball effect will motivate you to keep going as your results compound. All you have to do is try.

posts.com:
>>27987910
I am >>27987841 so not the person who wrote the advice. To me, setting goals is not really about discipline or at least not in the pragmatic sense. I see it more as a means for measure or description of a setting. In a way it is more of a depiction of something that is objective but it obviously can have a meritocratic usage to say a person has passed/failed something which probably isn't good for you if you have a underachiever complex.

But if you play with it poetically, i.e goals to be an objective future. You set your objective future... Being objective of the future. Heading towards a future in an objective way... I think you get the point. You don't need to worry about the meritocratic implications so much.

So when thinking about discipline in comparison, that is more of an expectation/prescription for when certain actions should be repeated or sustained I think. Something that is more or a method to get to the objective.

>I'm gonna go ahead and build the to-do list from the biggest achievement I want to make in 5 years to the smallest

If any of the smaller achievements can make the bigger achievements easier or achieve in the long-run that is a good thing just like an investment. Then that would be part of the "method" that defines your "discipline" because you're still going for the bigger achievements and already obtaining the smaller achievements are going to part of what makes it possible to do so.

Even if you don't see your smaller achievements you set to directly relate to your bigger achievements, you can at least use the momentum of the smaller achievements to fulfill your sense of productivity and feed your mindset to work on the bigger achievements you desire. You just need to keep conditioning yourself to take the actions that make sense to what you want to achieve.

You can understand why things work or fail relative to how long things take when you set deadlines. It is more about learning rather than failing or suceeding.

Say my goal is to buy a car in the next five years, how would you go around building such a pyramid?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27988278
That depends entirely on where you're starting from. Let's say the bare beginning: you're a teen just out of highschool with no savings and no job. A car is your goal in 5 years. First you need an idea of how much money you need to save for the kind of car you're looking to buy. Let's say $5,000 for a car. You first need a job to get that money. So your small goals today are to apply for jobs. Once you have one, your goal then is to save to the $5,000. That's $1,000 a year over the next 5, so monthly you want to be saving $83, weekly only $20 basically. We just took that significant goal of having $5,000 and turned it into a stupidly easy goal on putting up $20 a week, the only hard part is disciplining yourself not to touch that money once it builds up. You can speed this up by getting a better paying job or working more hours and socking away more, but, no matter what the specifics, the point is that you are earning money, and putting a reasonable and doable amount away consistently without touching it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27988278
I am >>27988255. Assuming the car price is going to be purchased within a fixed budget but you as the purchaser will not be able to save anything at all based on your current income and spending habits for the next 5 years and also not going to be taking on any private or commercial loans.

Obviously you will have to identify what you need to start doing and/or stop doing so that you have the funds in 5 years time. But you may not even be able to get the car if you don't have the means to raise money though, but let's say you could and at least had a job that you do not need to change.

I would list out the part-time jobs available and how much they pay, limit money only to neccessities, cheaper bill providers, don't spend on annual subscriptions like netflix, selling things you already own. Then break them into smaller goals to raise funds for the car but I would set the budget for the car to be based on what will be raised 30 months from now.

Set first goal to make monthly savings based on what was cut and cheaper bills and deadline will be 6 months to transition. Set second goal to find cheaper billing providers, 6 months deadline to transition. Third goal to start applying jobs available p/t by the end of first month, fourth would be to start p/t work within the year.

In 18 months I would establish what my monthly income and savings are going to amount to in the next by next year which will be month 30. If necessary I would consider moving or roomate/subtenant to save more, get a new p/t job and set a deadline for month 30, also consider selling items too if I want to afford a more expensive car. On month 30 set goal to have remaining income and savings due in remaining 30 months.

I tend think frugally about money and live in austerity when I need to raise funds. The real challenge is actually picking what to do and then committing to it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27988019
Don't listen to all the blackpillers in this thread and elsewhere because they're poison that serve no purpose except to fill you with doubt and to feel better about themselves if their own LDR failed (on the logic of "it's not my fault my LDR failed! all LDRs are doomed to fail... and.. uh.. they aren't even *real* relationships anyway so there!)

I'm not going to pretend that LDRs aren't difficult to keep up long-term, but the first step is to remind yourself that LDRs are increasingly common and lots of people find success in them. It's objectively wrong to say they're not a relationship. In fact I'd go as far as to argue they've got a higher chance of success for slower-paced, shyer and more introverted people because they have less pressure and can take things at a more comfortable pace.

As for suggestions, it depends on the type of people you are. If you're open and curious then you can't go wrong by asking a lot of deep questions about your future hopes, what you're attracted to etc. Not only does that make for a ton of conversation but it'll allow you to connect on a deeper level, especially if you really engage back and forth with your thoughts (as opposed to something like "that's interesting, I agree"). If you can't think of ideas, then tests and quizes can help (for example MBTI - even if you don't believe it's accurate then it can still be used as a jumping off point for conversation as you discuss the similarities and differences in your results)

If you're not that way inclined though, it's good to watch movies online together, particularly romantic ones. There's a lot of websites that let you talk and stream at the same time such as cytube and free4talk. Games are another obvious thing, even if you're not the gaming sort then you can just treat it as a virtual space to talk in and go on virtual dates, such as exploring VRchat worlds together. If you're from different countries then make an effort to get to know each other's cultures.
